events.title: Live Data Center Migrations

events.abstract: Whether you’re using Chef, Puppet or Ansible, you’re going to need a set of tools which help enable you to develop and test your infrastructure. One set of tools that we use at the OSU Open Source Lab is test-kitchen coupled with InSpec. Test-kitchen provides a test harness to execute infrastructure code on one or more platforms in isolation. InSpec provides a way to ensure your infrastructure code passes tests and compliance in a way separate from your configuration management. Together, this provides a very powerful platform for developing infrastructure code and testing it as well.
events.title: Introduction to test-kitchen and InSpec

events.abstract: The '90s saw a number of classic, and often times unintentionally hilarious, computer hacker movies that portray an imaginative and largely inaccurate view of how computers actually work. What would these movies look like today? This session demonstrates the benefits of taking a cloud-native approach to designing applications in the context of the movie WarGames. Through a series of demos, attendees will learn how to deploy container-native applications and use Kubernetes Operators to dynamically scale the application infrastructure according to growing user demands.
events.title: Shall We Play a Game? Modernizing WarGames Using Cloud-Native Technologies

events.abstract: At the Go Hardware Hack Session featuring TinyGo you will get to program robots, drones, and sensors, all using the programming language Go!
events.title: Go Hardware Hack Session featuring TinyGo

events.abstract: At first glance, it may seem impossible to build an open and authentic community for a company-based open source project when you need to balance the needs of the company with those of the community. In this talk, learn how to build a thriving community by understanding the intrinsic motivations of community members while providing opportunities for them to grow and have a voice in the community. There will also be a discussion on how diverse viewpoints and being responsive to contributions is beneficial to both  the community and the company.
events.title: Building a thriving community in (for-profit) open source projects

events.abstract: Data processing is not a straightforward process, it involves tasks as data collection with pre-processing to aggregation and storage. This workflow works, but it has some costs associated where performance is not always ideal: data processing is expensive and also takes time. On the other side, Stream Processing is the ability to perform data processing while the data is still in motion. In this presentation, we will introduce how Logging and Stream Processing can take data analysis to the next level, reducing the time to get results, alerting and featuring machine learning.
events.title: Logging and Stream Processing on the Edge

events.abstract: Ensuring reliable data storage and delivery with Apache Kafka can be challenging. Those trying to implement Kafka deal with critical questions such as: How can data order be at risk? How could data potentially be lost? How could records be accidently duplicated? This session explores essential components of building a lasting strategy for data integrity with Kafka.
events.title: Is Your Kafka Data in Working Order? Tactics for Overcoming Kafka Data Order Issues

events.abstract: This session will cap out the Sysadmin tutorial track, by discussing doing things at SCaLE and using Ansible as a means to deal with automation, and configuration management, at a scale beyond a couple of machines. Hands on tutorial will involve two VMs in network communication with each other, and provide a good starting place for folks interested in exploring this further.
events.title: Workshop: Ansible 101

events.abstract:
Serverless has become popular amognst developers because of its ergonomics and reduced operational complexity. However, the serverless model makes doing a few traditional things harder. stateful I will introduce 3 common stateful use-cases for applications viz. accessing, persisting & sharing data. Why are these hard with serverless and what are the different ways of solving these problems? 
 I will also share my learnings working with the user-community of the open-source GraphQL engine, . Hasura
events.title: Patterns to build stateful applications with serverless: solving the data problem

events.abstract: Lotus Petal Architecture is an interactive 3D data visualization toolset accessible from any web browser or mobile platform. Visual cues and hinting provide context. Any type of filter may be applied but the Lotus Chart structure is well suited for machine learning output and identifying growth trends across a data ecosystem. Built using the three.js library and extensible with node.js, it can be used to dynamically represent several thousand visual links on-screen at any one time. Because the schema is fractal there is no theoretical limit to the amount of data that can be referenced.
events.title: Lotus Petal Architecture: Link Building with Parametric Geometry

events.abstract: Bastille automates deployment and management of containers using a container technology old enough to buy you a drink! We've taken automation concepts learned from leading config management contenders and combined them with the ORIGINAL container technology. FreeBSD introduced containers in April 1999, pre-dating every other container technology available. Imagine a reliable container technology that has had two decades to work out bugs.Talk about production ready! This talk will outline design features and demonstrate secure container automation in the cloud and on the Raspberry Pi.
events.title: Bastille : Secure Container Automation for FreeBSD

events.abstract: Kubernetes is an open source project with a high velocity of PRs and releases. While the activity and interest in the project is awesome, communicating these changes to end users becomes difficult. For a long time, each release would generate a new release notes markdown document that required manual cleanup and curation. In recent months the format has been reconsidered and completely restructured. This talk will go over the history of Kubernetes release notes, the current state of relnotes.k8s.io, and future plans for automated publishing of release notes and notifications.
events.title: Building the next generation of release notes for Kubernetes

events.abstract: Wondering what has transpired in your favorite graphics applications over the last year? Join us for a recap of project development!
events.title: The State of LibreGraphics

events.abstract: Based on internal training given to Facebook engineers, this talk is a collection of tips and tricks for being more efficient and productive on the command line. Learn about convenient customizations, speedy shortcuts, useful utilities, and more advanced techniques to help you look like a command line pro.
events.title: Command Line Efficiency

events.abstract: Learn how to modernize your Java application monitoring and dashboarding with Prometheus and Grafana. There's a lot of information out there when it comes to monitoring a Kubernetes cluster with Prometheus, but, in the modern enterprise landscape, applications are still what matters. Learn how to leverage Prometheus and Grafana to build slick, modern monitoring dashboards and threshold logic for Java applications.
events.title: Monitoring Java Applications with Prometheus and Grafana

events.abstract:
There is an epic journey from reviewed source code to the code you 
 actually run on your computer, and things can go quietly wrong along 
 the way! 
 
 Reproducible Builds gives a project confidence that the journey from 
 source code to binary code gets you there and back again.
events.title: There and Back Again, Reproducibly!

events.abstract: In the era dynamic platforms, management of entry points is a great challenge, with the large amounts of application deployments requiring entry points to update often. Learn how to overcome this complexity, and build reliable entry points, focusing your energy on what matters to you. Our session will define what a modern edge router, reverse proxy and load-balancer are. We'll present concepts and advanced features which overcome the platform entry point challenges. Finally, we'll dig deeper and show how these solutions can scale and be fault tolerant.
events.title: Easy HTTPS for Your Microservice Architectures

events.abstract: The constantly shifting world of technology is always providing developers with new things to learn: languages, tools, techniques. Keeping your skills current is a full-time job. There are lots of resources out there to use, but you need to evaluate which ones work for you, and how best to use them. This session will highlight the various learning formats, help you pick the one that best fits you or your group, allow you to evaluate whether it's working, and tell you what to do when it doesn't.
events.title: Continuous Learning for Developers
